Today, I tried the latest IBM Java VM for Linux, and gave the VM about 1.5GB
of heap space. In the first 10 minutes, from the same seeds, it collected:
   - 66,550 successful fetches
   - 556MB of uncompressed ARCs

That works out to about:
   - 110 resources per second
   - 925KB of archivable material per second (~7Mbit inflow)

The resource count numbers for these runs are slightly inflated by the 
fact that we're considering DNS lookups as resource fetches, and writing 
them to the ARCs as well. 

Just after the 10 minute mark, the first of a number of long pauses 
(Java VM garbage-collections) began, and so progress after that point
was significantly slower. 

At the 20 minute mark, it had only collected an additional 21,000 
resources; at 30 minutes, only another 10,000 resources. 

Progress thereafteer slowed to a trickle, with out-of-memory errors 
starting at about the 35 minute mark, with 97,000 resources and 93MBs 
of material collected.

- Gordon

> Just as a quick progress check, I ran the current dev crawler on Crawl09 (
> the 2GB RAM machine) with eight broad seeds and 200 worker threads. I 
> still only assigned it 384MB of heap space. 
> 
> It ran for about 10 minutes before gumming up, mostly with out-of-memory
> errors, which slowed its progress to a trickle. 
> 
> In that time it collected over 27,000 URIs, resulting in about 98MBs of 
> compressed arc.gz information. (That'd be about 220MBs uncompressed.)
> 
> So the rates per this "burst" crawl are approximately:
>  - 45 resources/URIs per second
>  - 350K of uncompressed archivable material per second
> 
> Simply offering it more memory would likely result in a nearly-linear
> growth in URIs visited before memory exhaustion, but most likely at a 
> slower rate.
> 
> It's reasonable to project that, before further optimization, we
> could scale up about 6 times by using more of the available memory:
> around 150,000 visited URIs in a bit over an hour. 
> 
> - Gordon
